title: State Schooldata Packages
text: section contains universal instructions apply 49 state schooldata packages.

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: NEVER use Urban Institute API, NCES CCD, federal data source — entire point packages provide STATE-LEVEL data directly state . Federal sources aggregate/transform data differently lose state-specific details. state DOE source broken, FIX find alternative STATE source — fall back federal data.

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: Maximum 5 background tasks running simultaneously launching multiple agents (e.g., mass audits), batch groups 5 Wait current batch complete launching next batch

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: NEVER push directly main. changes must go PRs auto-merge:
code: # 1. Create feature branch git checkout -b fix/description-of-change  # 2. Make changes, commit git add -A git commit -m "Fix: description of change"  # 3. Push and create PR with auto-merge git push -u origin fix/description-of-change gh pr create --title "Fix: description" --body "Description of changes" gh pr merge --auto --squash  # 4. Clean up stale branches after PR merges git checkout main && git pull && git fetch --prune origin

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: Clean stale branches every time touch package:
code: # Delete local branches merged to main git branch --merged main | grep -v main | xargs -r git branch -d  # Prune remote tracking branches git fetch --prune origin

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: PRs auto-merge CI checks pass: - R-CMD-check (0 errors, 0 warnings) - Python tests (py{st}schooldata exists) - pkgdown build (vignettes must render) CI fails, fix issue push - auto-merge triggers checks pass.

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: PRs merged CI passes. Run checks locally opening PR:

title: State Schooldata Packages
code: # R package check (required) devtools::check()  # Python tests (required) system("pip install -e ./py{st}schooldata && pytest tests/test_py{st}schooldata.py -v")  # pkgdown build (required) pkgdown::build_site()

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: opening PR, verify: - [ ] devtools::check() — 0 errors, 0 warnings - [ ] pytest tests/test_py{st}schooldata.py — tests pass - [ ] pkgdown::build_site() — builds without errors - [ ] Vignettes render (eval=FALSE hacks)

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: package includes tests/testthat/test-pipeline-live.R LIVE network tests.

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: URL Availability - HTTP 200 checks File Download - Verify actual file (HTML error) File Parsing - readxl/readr succeeds Column Structure - Expected columns exist get_raw_enr() - Raw data function works Data Quality - Inf/NaN, non-negative counts Aggregation - State total > 0 Output Fidelity - tidy=TRUE matches raw

title: State Schooldata Packages
code: devtools::test(filter = "pipeline-live")

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: tidy=TRUE MUST maintain fidelity raw, unprocessed data: - Enrollment counts tidy format must exactly match wide format - rounding transformation counts tidying - Percentages calculated fresh counts preserved - State aggregates sums school-level data

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: NEVER use man/figures/ generate_readme_figs.R README images. README images MUST come pkgdown-generated vignette output auto-update merge: : Vignette figures regenerate automatically pkgdown builds. Manual man/figures/ requires running separate script easy forget, causing stale/broken images.
code: ![Chart name](https://almartin82.github.io/{package}/articles/{vignette}_files/figure-html/{chunk-name}-1.png)

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: CRITICAL RULE (2026-01-08): code blocks README MUST match code vignette EXACTLY (1:1 correspondence).

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: Idaho fix revealed critical bugs README code didn’t match vignettes: - Wrong district names (lowercase vs CAPS) - Text claims contradicted actual data - Missing data output examples

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: Every story/section README MUST follow structure: Claim: factual statement data Explication: Brief explanation matters Code: R code fetches analyzes data (MUST exist vignette) Code Output: Data table/print statement showing actual values (REQUIRED) Visualization: Chart vignette (auto-generated pkgdown)

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: state-deploy skill verifies deployment: - Extracts README code blocks - Searches vignettes EXACT matches - Fails deployment code found vignettes - Randomly audits packages claim accuracy

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: ❌ Wrong district/entity names (case sensitivity, typos) ❌ Text claims contradict data ❌ Broken code fails silently ❌ Missing data output ✅ Verified, accurate, reproducible examples

title: State Schooldata Packages
code: ### 1. State enrollment grew 28% since 2002  State added 68,000 students from 2002 to 2026, bucking national trends.  ```r library(arschooldata) library(dplyr)  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2002:2026)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2002, 2026)) %>%   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students),          pct_change = round((n_students / lag(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1)) # Prints: 2002=XXX, 2026=YYY, change=ZZZ, pct=PP.P%

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: Florida-specific package documentation notes.

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: Available Years: 2021-2025 Data Source: Florida Department Education

title: State Schooldata Packages
text: unique state-specific documentation time.

title: TODO: Package Improvements
text: Problem: pkgdown’s data_home_sidebar_links function always calls cran_link() makes HTTP requests cloud.r-project.org bioconductor.org, causing timeouts Root cause: function eagerly evaluates default sidebar components even ’re structure Solution: Use custom sidebar HTML (pkgdown/sidebar.html) bypasses default component generation entirely See commit fix details

title: TODO: Package Improvements
text: Vignette enrollment_hooks.Rmd dynamically fetches data FLDOE FLDOE servers slow, vignette build may timeout Package uses caching (rappdirs) downloaded data httr timeout set 300 seconds download functions issues occur: Consider pre-computing vignette data using knitr caching

what: 1. Florida is America’s fourth-largest school system
title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Florida public schools serve nearly 3 million students, trailing California, Texas, New York.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2024, use_cache = TRUE)  state_totals <- enr |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   select(end_year, n_students) |>   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students),          pct_change = round(change / lag(n_students) * 100, 2))  state_totals #>    end_year n_students change pct_change #> 1      2015    2750108     NA         NA #> 2      2016    2785286  35178       1.28 #> 3      2017    2810249  24963       0.90 #> 4      2018    2826290  16041       0.57 #> 5      2019    2840029  13739       0.49 #> 6      2020    2852303  12274       0.43 #> 7      2021    2784931 -67372      -2.36 #> 8      2022    2826573  41642       1.50 #> 9      2023    2864292  37719       1.33 #> 10     2024    2865908   1616       0.06 ggplot(state_totals, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#FF6600") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#FF6600") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Florida Public School Enrollment (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Nearly 3 million students in the Sunshine State",     x = "School Year (ending)",     y = "Total Enrollment"   )

what: 2. Miami-Dade is larger than most states
title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Miami-Dade County Public Schools, 340,000+ students, fourth-largest school district America.
code: enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024, use_cache = TRUE)  top_10 <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   arrange(desc(n_students)) |>   head(10) |>   select(district_name, n_students)  top_10 #>    district_name n_students #> 1     MIAMI-DADE     337610 #> 2        BROWARD     251397 #> 3   HILLSBOROUGH     224144 #> 4         ORANGE     207695 #> 5     PALM BEACH     191390 #> 6          DUVAL     129083 #> 7           POLK     115990 #> 8            LEE      99952 #> 9       PINELLAS      90969 #> 10         PASCO      85808 top_10 |>   mutate(district_name = forcats::fct_reorder(district_name, n_students)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = n_students, y = district_name)) +   geom_col(fill = "#FF6600") +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Florida's 10 Largest School Districts (2024)",     x = "Total Enrollment",     y = NULL   )

title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: states saw sharp declines, Florida’s enrollment dipped briefly 2021 since rebounded.
code: covid <- enr |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          end_year >= 2019) |>   select(end_year, n_students) |>   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students))  covid #>   end_year n_students change #> 1     2019    2840029     NA #> 2     2020    2852303  12274 #> 3     2021    2784931 -67372 #> 4     2022    2826573  41642 #> 5     2023    2864292  37719 #> 6     2024    2865908   1616

title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Hispanic students now comprise 35% Florida enrollment, surpassing white students.
code: demographics <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white", "black", "asian", "multiracial")) |>   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) |>   select(subgroup, n_students, pct) |>   arrange(desc(n_students))  demographics #>      subgroup n_students  pct #> 1    hispanic    1066935 37.2 #> 2       white     988822 34.5 #> 3       black     599867 20.9 #> 4 multiracial     119907  4.2 #> 5       asian      81688  2.9 demographics |>   mutate(subgroup = forcats::fct_reorder(subgroup, n_students)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = n_students, y = subgroup, fill = subgroup)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = paste0(pct, "%")), hjust = -0.1) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma, expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +   labs(     title = "Florida Student Demographics (2024)",     subtitle = "Hispanic students are now the plurality",     x = "Number of Students",     y = NULL   )

what: 5. Central Florida is the growth engine
title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Orange, Osceola, Polk counties among fastest-growing, driven Orlando metro boom.
code: central_fl <- enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Orange|Osceola|Polk", district_name),          end_year %in% c(2015, 2024)) |>   group_by(district_name) |>   summarize(     y2015 = n_students[end_year == 2015],     y2024 = n_students[end_year == 2024],     pct_change = round((y2024 / y2015 - 1) * 100, 1),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   arrange(desc(pct_change))  central_fl #> # A tibble: 0 × 4 #> # ℹ 4 variables: district_name <chr>, y2015 <dbl>, y2024 <dbl>, #> #   pct_change <dbl>

title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: South Florida’s two largest districts losing students families relocate.
code: south_fl <- enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Broward|Miami-Dade", district_name),          end_year >= 2018) |>   select(end_year, district_name, n_students) |>   pivot_wider(names_from = district_name, values_from = n_students)  south_fl #> # A tibble: 0 × 1 #> # ℹ 1 variable: end_year <int> enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Broward|Miami-Dade", district_name),          end_year >= 2018) |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "South Florida's Enrollment Decline",     x = "School Year",     y = "Enrollment",     color = "District"   )

what: 7. Florida Virtual School is a district unto itself
title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Florida Virtual School (FLVS) serves tens thousands students statewide.
code: virtual <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Virtual|FLVS", district_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) |>   select(district_name, n_students)  virtual #>   district_name n_students #> 1    FL VIRTUAL       8874

title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Florida kindergarten enrollment relatively stable, unlike states sharp K declines.

title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Florida significant Black student population, concentrated South Florida Jacksonville region.
code: black_enr <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "black") |>   select(subgroup, n_students, pct)  black_enr #>   subgroup n_students       pct #> 1    black     599867 0.2093113

title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Florida organizes schools county, 67 county districts (plus specialty districts). structure differs states.
code: county_count <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   summarize(     n_districts = n_distinct(district_name),     total_students = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE)   )  county_count #>   n_districts total_students #> 1          76        2865908

what: 11. Tampa Bay is catching up to South Florida
title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Hillsborough Pinellas counties represent Florida’s major metro area. South Florida declines, Tampa Bay held steady.
code: tampa <- enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Hillsborough|Pinellas|Pasco", district_name)) |>   group_by(district_name) |>   summarize(     y2015 = n_students[end_year == 2015],     y2024 = n_students[end_year == 2024],     pct_change = round((y2024 / y2015 - 1) * 100, 1),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   arrange(desc(y2024))  tampa #> # A tibble: 0 × 4 #> # ℹ 4 variables: district_name <chr>, y2015 <dbl>, y2024 <dbl>, #> #   pct_change <dbl> enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Hillsborough|Pinellas|Pasco", district_name)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +   labs(     title = "Tampa Bay Metro Enrollment Trends (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Hillsborough stable, Pasco growing, Pinellas declining",     x = "School Year",     y = "Enrollment",     color = "County"   )

title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Duval County (Jacksonville) often flies radar, ’s Florida’s 6th largest district 125,000 students.
code: jax <- enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Duval", district_name)) |>   select(end_year, district_name, n_students) |>   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students))  jax #> [1] end_year      district_name n_students    change        #> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names) jax |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#0066CC") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#0066CC") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Duval County (Jacksonville) Enrollment (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Florida's 6th largest district",     x = "School Year",     y = "Total Enrollment"   )

what: 13. Hispanic enrollment surpassed White for the first time
title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: demographic milestone: Hispanic student enrollment overtaken White enrollment Florida, reflecting broader population shifts.
code: crossover <- enr |>   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white")) |>   select(end_year, subgroup, n_students) |>   pivot_wider(names_from = subgroup, values_from = n_students)  crossover #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #>    end_year   white hispanic #>       <int>   <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1     2015 1108227   846425 #>  2     2016 1101823   879982 #>  3     2017 1089439   912300 #>  4     2018 1077811   937352 #>  5     2019 1063838   963338 #>  6     2020 1054580   986005 #>  7     2021 1016772   974588 #>  8     2022 1021630  1003659 #>  9     2023 1014065  1043390 #> 10     2024  988822  1066935 enr |>   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white")) |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = subgroup)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   scale_color_manual(values = c("hispanic" = "#FF6600", "white" = "#3399CC"),                      labels = c("Hispanic", "White")) +   labs(     title = "The Hispanic-White Enrollment Crossover",     subtitle = "Hispanic students now outnumber White students in Florida",     x = "School Year",     y = "Number of Students",     color = "Group"   )

what: 14. Small rural counties face steep declines
title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: large metros grow, many Florida’s smallest counties losing students rapidly.
code: # Get the first and last year for comparison first_year <- min(enr$end_year) last_year <- max(enr$end_year)  county_change <- enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          end_year %in% c(first_year, last_year)) |>   group_by(district_name) |>   filter(n() == 2) |>  # Only counties with both years   summarize(     y_first = n_students[end_year == first_year],     y_last = n_students[end_year == last_year],     change = y_last - y_first,     pct_change = round((y_last / y_first - 1) * 100, 1),     .groups = "drop"   )  # Counties losing the most (by %) declining <- county_change |>   filter(y_first > 1000) |>  # Exclude tiny counties   arrange(pct_change) |>   head(10)  declining #> # A tibble: 10 × 5 #>    district_name y_first y_last change pct_change #>    <chr>           <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>      <dbl> #>  1 GADSDEN          5837   4598  -1239      -21.2 #>  2 LIBERTY          1330   1156   -174      -13.1 #>  3 PINELLAS       103754  90969 -12785      -12.3 #>  4 LAFAYETTE        1132   1007   -125      -11   #>  5 MADISON          2498   2228   -270      -10.8 #>  6 JACKSON          6726   6037   -689      -10.2 #>  7 DESOTO           4658   4199   -459       -9.9 #>  8 HARDEE           5095   4598   -497       -9.8 #>  9 TAYLOR           2885   2602   -283       -9.8 #> 10 CALHOUN          2149   1942   -207       -9.6 declining |>   mutate(district_name = forcats::fct_reorder(district_name, pct_change)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = pct_change, y = district_name)) +   geom_col(fill = "#CC3333") +   labs(     title = paste0("Florida's Fastest Declining Counties (", first_year, "-", last_year, ")"),     subtitle = "Percent change in total enrollment",     x = "Percent Change",     y = NULL   )

what: 15. Multiracial students are the fastest-growing demographic
title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Hispanic students largest group, multiracial student enrollment grown highest rate percentage-wise since 2015 (34.9% growth, compared 26.1% Hispanic students 15.3% Asian students).
code: demo_trend <- enr |>   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white", "black", "asian", "multiracial")) |>   select(end_year, subgroup, n_students) |>   group_by(subgroup) |>   mutate(pct_change = round((n_students / first(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1)) |>   ungroup()  demo_trend |>   filter(end_year == 2024) |>   arrange(desc(pct_change)) #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   end_year subgroup    n_students pct_change #>      <int> <chr>            <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1     2024 multiracial     119907       34.9 #> 2     2024 hispanic       1066935       26.1 #> 3     2024 asian            81688       15.3 #> 4     2024 black           599867       -4.2 #> 5     2024 white           988822      -10.8 demo_trend |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = pct_change, color = subgroup)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.5) +   scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +   labs(     title = "Demographic Growth Trends (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Percent change from 2015 baseline",     x = "School Year",     y = "Percent Change from 2015",     color = "Subgroup"   )

title: 15 Insights from Florida School Enrollment Data
text: Florida’s school enrollment data reveals: Continued growth: Florida keeps growing major states decline Demographic crossover: Hispanic students now outnumber White students, Asian students growing fastest Regional divergence: Central Florida Tampa Bay grow, South Florida rural areas shrink Virtual pioneer: FLVS shows Florida’s embrace online education County structure: 67 county districts create unique administrative system Hidden giants: Jacksonville (Duval) often overlooked major district patterns shape education policy across Sunshine State. Data sourced Florida Department Education.

 LAPACK version 3.12.0 #>  #> locale: #>  [1] LC_CTYPE=C.UTF-8       LC_NUMERIC=C           LC_TIME=C.UTF-8        #>  [4] LC_COLLATE=C.UTF-8     LC_MONETARY=C.UTF-8    LC_MESSAGES=C.UTF-8    #>  [7] LC_PAPER=C.UTF-8       LC_NAME=C              LC_ADDRESS=C           #> [10] LC_TELEPHONE=C         LC_MEASUREMENT=C.UTF-8 LC_IDENTIFICATION=C    #>  #> time zone: UTC #> tzcode source: system (glibc) #>  #> attached base packages: #> [1] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base      #>  #> other attached packages: #> [1] ggplot2_4.0.1      tidyr_1.3.2        dplyr_1.1.4        flschooldata_0.1.0 #>  #> loaded via a namespace (and not attached): #>  [1] gtable_0.3.6       jsonlite_2.0.0     compiler_4.5.2     tidyselect_1.2.1   #>  [5] jquerylib_0.1.4    systemfonts_1.3.1  scales_1.4.0       textshaping_1.0.4  #>  [9] readxl_1.4.5       yaml_2.3.12        fastmap_1.2.0      R6_2.6.1           #> [13] labeling_0.4.3     generics_0.1.4     curl_7.0.0         knitr_1.51         #> [17] forcats_1.0.1      tibble_3.3.1       desc_1.4.3         bslib_0.9.0        #> [21] pillar_1.11.1      RColorBrewer_1.1-3 rlang_1.1.7        utf8_1.2.6         #> [25] cachem_1.1.0       xfun_0.55          S7_0.2.1           fs_1.6.6           #> [29] sass_0.4.10        cli_3.6.5          withr_3.0.2        pkgdown_2.2.0      #> [33] magrittr_2.0.4     digest_0.6.39      grid_4.5.2         rappdirs_0.3.3     #> [37] lifecycle_1.0.5    vctrs_0.7.0        evaluate_1.0.5     glue_1.8.0         #> [41] cellranger_1.1.0   farver_2.1.2       codetools_0.2-20   ragg_1.5.0         #> [45] httr_1.4.7         rmarkdown_2.30     purrr_1.2.1        tools_4.5.2        #> [49] pkgconfig_2.0.3    htmltools_0.5.9

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
what: 1. Florida is America’s fourth-largest school system
title: Florida School Data
text: Florida public schools serve nearly 3 million students, trailing California, Texas, New York. One function call pulls R.
code: library(flschooldata) library(dplyr)  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2014:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students))

what: 2. Miami-Dade is larger than most states
title: Florida School Data
text: Miami-Dade County Public Schools, 340,000+ students, fourth-largest school district America enrolls students several entire states.
code: enr_2025 <- fetch_enr(2025)  enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(10) %>%   select(district_name, n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
title: Florida School Data
text: states saw sharp declines, Florida’s enrollment dipped briefly 2021 since rebounded, fueled -migration states.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2019:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students))

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
title: Florida School Data
text: Hispanic students now comprise 35% Florida enrollment, surpassing white students become largest demographic group statewide.
code: enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white", "black", "asian", "multiracial")) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) %>%   select(subgroup, n_students, pct) %>%   arrange(desc(n_students))

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
what: 5. Central Florida is the growth engine
title: Florida School Data
text: Orange, Osceola, Polk counties Central Florida among fastest-growing state, driven Orlando metro boom.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2014:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Orange|Osceola|Polk", district_name)) %>%   group_by(district_name) %>%   summarize(     y2014 = n_students[end_year == 2014],     y2025 = n_students[end_year == 2025],     pct_change = round((y2025 / y2014 - 1) * 100, 1)   ) %>%   arrange(desc(pct_change))

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
title: Florida School Data
text: South Florida’s two largest districts losing students years families relocate Central Florida state.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2018:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Broward|Miami-Dade", district_name)) %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students) %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = district_name, values_from = n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
what: 7. Florida Virtual School is a district unto itself
title: Florida School Data
text: Florida Virtual School (FLVS) serves tens thousands students statewide, making Florida pioneer virtual education.
code: enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Virtual|FLVS", district_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) %>%   select(district_name, n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
title: Florida School Data
text: Florida kindergarten enrollment relatively stable, unlike states sharp K declines–reflecting Florida’s continued population growth.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2019:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("K", "01", "05", "09")) %>%   select(end_year, grade_level, n_students) %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = grade_level, values_from = n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
title: Florida School Data
text: Florida significant Black student population, concentrated South Florida Jacksonville/North Florida region.
code: enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "black", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) %>%   head(10) %>%   select(district_name, n_students, pct)

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
what: 10. Florida has one district per county
title: Florida School Data
text: Unlike states hundreds small districts, Florida exactly 67 county-based school districts (plus special-purpose districts), making statewide analysis cleaner.
code: enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   summarize(     n_districts = n(),     total_students = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE),     avg_per_district = round(mean(n_students, na.rm = TRUE))   )

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
what: 11. Tampa Bay is catching up to South Florida
title: Florida School Data
text: Hillsborough, Pinellas, Pasco counties represent Florida’s major metro area. South Florida declines, Tampa Bay held steady grown.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Hillsborough|Pinellas|Pasco", district_name)) %>%   group_by(district_name) %>%   summarize(     y2015 = n_students[end_year == 2015],     y2025 = n_students[end_year == 2025],     pct_change = round((y2025 / y2015 - 1) * 100, 1)   ) %>%   arrange(desc(y2025))

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
title: Florida School Data
text: Duval County (Jacksonville) often flies radar, ’s Florida’s 6th largest district 125,000 students.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Duval", district_name)) %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students) %>%   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students))

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
what: 13. Hispanic enrollment surpassed White for the first time
title: Florida School Data
text: demographic milestone: Hispanic student enrollment overtaken White enrollment Florida, reflecting state’s changing population.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white")) %>%   select(end_year, subgroup, n_students) %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = subgroup, values_from = n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
what: 14. Small rural counties face steep declines
title: Florida School Data
text: large metros grow, many Florida’s smallest counties losing students rapidly, often double-digit percentages.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          end_year %in% c(2015, 2025)) %>%   group_by(district_name) %>%   summarize(     y2015 = n_students[end_year == 2015],     y2025 = n_students[end_year == 2025],     pct_change = round((y2025 / y2015 - 1) * 100, 1)   ) %>%   arrange(pct_change) %>%   head(10)

previous_headings: What can you find with flschooldata?
what: 15. Multiracial students are the fastest-growing demographic
title: Florida School Data
text: Hispanic students largest group, multiracial student enrollment grown highest rate percentage-wise since 2015 (34.9% growth, compared 26.1% Hispanic students 15.3% Asian students).
code: library(flschooldata) library(dplyr)  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2024)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white", "black", "asian", "multiracial")) %>%   group_by(subgroup) %>%   summarize(     y2015 = n_students[end_year == 2015],     y2024 = n_students[end_year == 2024],     pct_change = round((y2024 / y2015 - 1) * 100, 1)   ) %>%   arrange(desc(pct_change))

title: Florida School Data
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("almartin82/flschooldata")

title: Florida School Data
code: library(flschooldata) library(dplyr)  # Fetch one year enr_2025 <- fetch_enr(2025)  # Fetch multiple years enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2020:2025)  # State totals enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  # District breakdown enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students))  # Miami-Dade County (district 13) enr_2025 %>%   filter(district_id == "13", subgroup == "total_enrollment")

title: Florida School Data
code: import pyflschooldata as fl  # Check available years years = fl.get_available_years() print(f"Data available: {years['min_year']}-{years['max_year']}")  # Fetch one year df = fl.fetch_enr(2025)  # Fetch multiple years df_multi = fl.fetch_enr_multi([2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, 2025])  # State totals state_total = df[(df['is_state'] == True) &                  (df['subgroup'] == 'total_enrollment') &                  (df['grade_level'] == 'TOTAL')]  # District breakdown districts = df[(df['is_district'] == True) &                (df['subgroup'] == 'total_enrollment') &                (df['grade_level'] == 'TOTAL')].sort_values('n_students', ascending=False)

title: Florida School Data
text: Data sourced Florida Department Education.

title: Florida School Data
text: Levels: State, district (67 county + special), school (~4,500) Demographics: White, Black, Hispanic, Asian, American Indian, Pacific Islander, Two Races Gender: Male, Female Grade levels: Pre-K 12

title: Florida School Data
text: 67 county districts: Codes 01-67 (one per county) Special districts: Codes 71-75 (lab schools, FL School Deaf/Blind) School numbers: 4-digit codes Combined ID: DD-SSSS format (e.g., “13-0021” Miami-Dade school)

title: Florida School Data
text: Pre-2014 data limited demographics (FTE files ) Charter school identification directly available membership files ESE, ELL, free/reduced lunch separate files (yet integrated)

title: Fetch Florida enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: Downloads processes enrollment data Florida Department Education (FLDOE). Returns school membership data including breakdowns grade level race/ethnicity.

title: Fetch Florida enrollment data — fetch_enr
code: fetch_enr(end_year, tidy = TRUE, use_cache = TRUE)

title: Fetch Florida enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: end_year school year. Year end academic year - eg 2023-24 school year year '2024'. Valid values 2008-2025. 2014-2025: Full demographic grade-level data membership files 2008-2013: District-level FTE data (limited demographics) tidy TRUE (default), returns data long (tidy) format subgroup column. FALSE, returns wide format. use_cache TRUE (default), uses locally cached data available. Set FALSE force re-download FLDOE.

title: Fetch Florida enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: Data frame enrollment data. Wide format includes columns district_id, campus_id, names, enrollment counts demographic/grade. Tidy format pivots counts subgroup grade_level columns.

title: Fetch Florida enrollment data — fetch_enr
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get 2024 enrollment data (2023-24 school year) enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024)  # Get wide format enr_wide <- fetch_enr(2024, tidy = FALSE)  # Force fresh download (ignore cache) enr_fresh <- fetch_enr(2024, use_cache = FALSE)  # Filter to Miami-Dade County (district 13) miami_dade <- enr_2024 |>   dplyr::filter(district_id == "13")  # Get state totals state_totals <- enr_2024 |>   dplyr::filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") } # }

what: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: Downloads combines enrollment data multiple school years.

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
code: fetch_enr_multi(end_years, tidy = TRUE, use_cache = TRUE)

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: end_years Vector school year ends (e.g., c(2022, 2023, 2024)) tidy TRUE (default), returns data long (tidy) format. use_cache TRUE (default), uses locally cached data available.

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: Combined data frame enrollment data requested years

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get 3 years of data enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2022:2024)  # Track enrollment trends enr_multi |>   dplyr::filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   dplyr::select(end_year, n_students)  # Compare Hispanic enrollment growth across years enr_multi |>   dplyr::filter(is_state, subgroup == "hispanic", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   dplyr::select(end_year, n_students, pct) } # }

what: Fetch Florida graduation rate data — fetch_graduation
title: Fetch Florida graduation rate data — fetch_graduation
text: Downloads processes 4-year cohort graduation rate data Florida Department Education (FLDOE).

title: Fetch Florida graduation rate data — fetch_graduation
code: fetch_graduation(end_year, level = "all", tidy = TRUE, use_cache = FALSE)

title: Fetch Florida graduation rate data — fetch_graduation
text: end_year School year end (e.g., 2024 2023-24 school year). Valid years: 2016-2024. See get_available_grad_years(). level One "state", "district", "school", "" (default). Controls geographic levels return. tidy TRUE (default), returns long format (one row per school-subgroup). FALSE, returns wide format (one row per school, subgroup columns). use_cache TRUE, uses cached data available. Default FALSE.

title: Fetch Florida graduation rate data — fetch_graduation
text: Data frame graduation rate data.

title: Fetch Florida graduation rate data — fetch_graduation
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get all 2024 graduation data in tidy format grad_2024 <- fetch_graduation(2024)  # Get state-level only grad_state <- fetch_graduation(2024, level = "state")  # Get district-level in wide format grad_district_wide <- fetch_graduation(2024, level = "district", tidy = FALSE)  # See available years get_available_grad_years() } # }

what: flschooldata: Fetch and Process Florida School Data — flschooldata-package
title: flschooldata: Fetch and Process Florida School Data — flschooldata-package
text: Downloads processes school data Florida Department Education (FLDOE). Provides functions fetching enrollment data including membership school, grade, race/ethnicity, transforming tidy format analysis.

title: flschooldata: Fetch and Process Florida School Data — flschooldata-package
text: fetch_enr Fetch enrollment data school year fetch_enr_multi Fetch enrollment data multiple years tidy_enr Transform wide data tidy (long) format id_enr_aggs Add aggregation level flags enr_grade_aggs Create grade-level aggregations

title: flschooldata: Fetch and Process Florida School Data — flschooldata-package
text: cache_status View cached data files clear_cache Remove cached data files

title: flschooldata: Fetch and Process Florida School Data — flschooldata-package
text: Florida uses county-based district system : District Codes: 2 digits (01-67 counties, 71-75 special districts) School Numbers: 4 digits (0001-9899 regular schools) Combined ID: District code + School number (e.g., "13-0021" Miami-Dade)

title: flschooldata: Fetch and Process Florida School Data — flschooldata-package
text: Data sourced Florida Department Education: Students Data: https://www.fldoe.org/accountability/data-sys/edu-info-accountability-services/pk-12-public-school-data-pubs-reports/students.stml FTE History: https://www.fldoe.org/finance/fl-edu-finance-program-fefp/fte-info/student-enrollment.stml Master School ID: https://eds.fldoe.org/EDS/MasterSchoolID/

title: flschooldata: Fetch and Process Florida School Data — flschooldata-package
text: Membership Grade/Race: 2014-present (current format) FTE Enrollment: 2008-present (Excel format) Historical archive data goes back format varies

title: flschooldata: Fetch and Process Florida School Data — flschooldata-package
text: Maintainer: Al Martin almartin@example.com

what: Get available years for Florida enrollment data — get_available_years

text: Returns range years available Florida Department Education (FLDOE). Data available 2007-08 school year (end_year = 2008) 2023-24 (end_year = 2024).

code: get_available_years()

title: Get available years for Florida enrollment data — get_available_years
text: list components: min_year Integer. earliest available year (2008). max_year Integer. recent available year (2024). description Character. description data availability.

title: Get available years for Florida enrollment data — get_available_years
text: Note: Years 2008-2013 limited demographic data (FTE files ). Full demographic grade-level data available 2014 onward.

title: Get available years for Florida enrollment data — get_available_years
